Short summary description of the place: Sri Lanka, officially the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka, is an island country in South Asia, located in the Indian Ocean to the southwest of the Bay of Bengal and to the southeast of the Arabian Sea.
History Phase 1 Small description: Evidence of human colonization in Sri Lanka appears at the site of Balangoda. Balangoda Man arrived on the island about 34,000 years ago and have been identified as Mesolithic hunter gatherers who lived in caves.
History Phase 2 Small description: The Pre Anuradhapura period or the Early kingdoms period of Sri Lankan history begins with the gradual onset of historical records in the final centuries of the prehistoric period and ending in 377 BC. According to the Mahavamsa, the original inhabitants of Sri Lanka are the Yakshas and northern Naga tribes.
History Phase 3 Small description: The Anuradhapura period was a period in the history of Sri Lanka of the Anuradhapura Kingdom from 377 BC to 1017 AD. The period begins when Pandukabhaya, King of Upatissa Nuwara moved the administration to Anuradhapura, becoming the kingdom's first monarch. Anuradhapura is heralded as an ancient cosmopolitan citadel with diverse populations.
History Phase 4 Small description: The Polonnaruwa period was a period in the history of Sri Lanka of the Kingdom of Polonnaruwa from 1056 to 1236. The period begins after the Chola conquest of Anuradhapura.
Government: Politics of Sri Lanka takes place in a framework of a semi-presidential representative democratic republic, whereby the President of Sri Lanka is both head of state and head of government, and of a multi-party system. Executive power is exercised by the government. Legislative power is vested in both the government and Parliament.
Geography: Sri Lanka, formerly called "Ceylon", is an island nation in the Indian Ocean, southeast of the Indian subcontinent, in a strategic location near major Indian Ocean sea lanes. The nation has a total area of 65,610 km², with 64,740 km² of land and 870 km² of water. Its coastline is 1,340 km (830 mi) long.
Small description 1: Dishes include rice and curry, pittu, kiribath, wholemeal roti, string hoppers, wattalapam, kottu, and hoppers.
Small description 2: In April, Sri Lankans celebrate the Buddhist and Hindu new year festival.
Small description 3: While the national sport in Sri Lanka is volleyball, by far the most popular sport in the country is cricket.
Small description 4: There are three main styles of Sri Lankan classical dance. They are, the Kandyan dances, low country dances and Sabaragamuwa dances.
Demographics - Languages: Sinhala and Tamil are the two official languages of Sri Lanka. The Constitution defines English as the link language

Short summary description of the place: South Africa, officially the Republic of South Africa (RSA), is the southernmost country in Africa. It is bounded to the south by 2,798 kilometres of coastline of Southern Africa stretching along the South Atlantic and Indian Oceans.
Other names: Union of South Africa, Republic of South Africa, Mzansi, Azania
History Phase 1 Small description: Various hominid species existed in South Africa from about three million years ago, starting with Australopithecus africanus. Archaeologists have recovered extensive fossil remains from a series of caves in Gauteng Province.
History Phase 2 Small description: Settlements of Bantu-speaking peoples, who were iron-using agriculturists and herdsmen, were already present south of the Limpopo River (now the northern border with Botswana and Zimbabwe) by the 4th or 5th century CE. They displaced, conquered and absorbed the original Khoisan speakers, the Khoikhoi and San peoples.
History Phase 3 Small description: At the time of European contact, the dominant ethnic group were Bantu-speaking peoples who had migrated from other parts of Africa about one thousand years before. The two major historic groups were the Xhosa and Zulu peoples. In 1487, the Portuguese explorer Bartolomeu Dias led the first European voyage to land in southern Africa.
History Phase 4 Small description: A century and a half after the discovery of the Cape sea route, Jan van Riebeeck established a victualling station at the Cape of Good Hope, at what would become Cape Town, on behalf of the Dutch East India Company.
Government: South Africa is a parliamentary republic, although unlike most such republics the President is both head of state and head of government, and depends for his tenure on the confidence of Parliament.
Geography: South Africa is located at the southernmost region of Africa, with a long coastline that stretches more than 2,500 km (1,553 mi) and along two oceans (the South Atlantic and the Indian).
Small description 1: South African art includes the oldest art objects in the world, which were discovered in a South African cave, and dated from 75,000 years ago.
Small description 2: The South African media sector is large, and South Africa is one of Africa's major media centres. While South Africa's many broadcasters and publications reflect the diversity of the population as a whole, the most commonly used language is English. However, all ten other official languages are represented to some extent or another.
Small description 3: South African cuisine is heavily meat-based and has spawned the distinctively South African social gathering known as the braai, a variation of the barbecue. South Africa has also developed into a major wine producer.
Small description 4: South Africa's most popular sports are soccer, rugby and cricket.
Demographics - Languages: Afrikaans, IsiNdebele, Sepedi, SeSotho sa Borwa, SiSwati, XiTsonga, SeTswana, TshiVenḓa, IsiXhosa, and IsiZulu

Short summary description of the place: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It shares land borders with Wales to the west and Scotland to the north-northwest.
History Phase 1 Small description: The earliest known occupation of Britain by humans was during the old stone age. This huge period saw many changes in the environment, including the ice ages that greatly affecting human settlement in the region.
History Phase 2 Small description: During the Neolithic era a more settled way of life was introduced although only a few actual settlement sites are known in Britain.
History Phase 3 Small description: It is generally thought that by 500 BC most people inhabiting the British Isles were speaking Common Brythonic. Iron Age Britons lived in organised tribal groups, ruled by a chieftain. As people became more numerous, wars broke out between opposing tribes.
History Phase 4 Small description: When England emerged from the collapse of the Roman Empire, the economy was in tatters and many of the towns abandoned. A rich artistic culture flourished under the Anglo-Saxons. They converted to Christianity in the 7th century and a network of monasteries and convents was built across England.
Government: As part of the United Kingdom, the basic political system in England is a constitutional monarchy and parliamentary system.
Chief Justice name: Ian Duncan Burnett, Baron Burnett of Maldon, PC
Geography: England includes the central and southern two-thirds of the island of Great Britain, plus some offshore islands. It is bordered by Scotland to the north, and Wales to the west.
Small description 1: Many ancient standing stone monuments were erected during the prehistoric period, including the Stonehenge. Romans who founded the first cities and towns such as London and introduced elaborate buildings. Medieval architecture's buildings were simple constructions. Since the 1930s various modernist forms have appeared.
Small description 2: Early authors wrote in Latin. The period of Old English literature provided the epic poem Beowulf. Middle English literature emerged with Geoffrey Chaucer, author of The Canterbury Tales. William Shakespeare, whose works include Hamlet, Romeo and Juliet, and Macbeth remains one of the most championed authors in English literature.
Small description 4: Traditional folk music of England is centuries old. Early English composers in classical music include Renaissance artists. In popular music, many English artists have been cited as the most influential musicians of all time, like The Beatles, Led Zeppelin, Pink Floyd, Elton John, and Queen.
Demographics - Languages: English, Polish, Punjabi, Urdu, Bengali, etc.
Religion 2 Name: Do not identify with a religion

Short summary description of the place: India, also known as the Republic of India is a country in South Asia. It is the seventh largest country by area with more than 1.3 billion people. It is the second most populous country as well as the most populous democracy in the world.
History Phase 1 Small description: The Indus Valley Civilisation was the first urban culture in South Asia.
History Phase 2 Small description: In the 6th and 7th centuries, the first devotional hymns were created in the Tamil language. They were imitated all over India and led to both the resurgence of Hinduism and the development of all modern languages of the subcontinent.
History Phase 3 Small description: The relative peace maintained by the Mughal Empire during much of the 17th century was a factor in India's economic expansion. By the early 18th century a number of European trading companies had established coastal outposts.
History Phase 4 Small description: The Indian Rebellion of 1857 led to the dissolution of the East India Company and the direct administration of India by the British government.
Government: India has a parliamentary republic with a multi-party system.
Geography: India comprises the bulk of the Indian subcontinent, lying atop the Indian tectonic plate, a part of the Indo-Australian Plate.
Small description 1: Much of Indian architecture, including the Taj Mahal, other works of Mughal architecture, and South Indian architecture, blends ancient local traditions with imported styles.
Small description 2: In the 20th century, Indian literature was influenced by the works of Bengali poet and novelist Rabindranath Tagore, who was a recipient of the Nobel Prize in Literature.
Small description 3: Indian dance also features diverse folk and classical forms. Among the better-known folk dances are the bhangra of Punjab, the bihu of Assam, the Jhumair and chhau of Jharkhand, Odisha and West Bengal, garba and dandiya of Gujarat, ghoomar of Rajasthan, and the lavani of Maharashtra.
Small description 4: The Indian film industry produces the world's most-watched cinema. South Indian cinema attracts more than 75% of national film revenue.
Demographics - Languages: Hindi, English, Assamese, Bengali, Bodo, Dogri, Gujarati, Kannada, Kashmiri, Kokborok, Konkani, Maithili, Malayalam, Manipuri, Marathi, Mizo, Nepali, Odia, Punjabi, Sanskrit, Santali, Sindhi, Tamil, Telugu, Urdu

Short summary description of the place: New Zealand is a sovereign island country in the southwestern Pacific Ocean. The country geographically comprises two main landmasses and around 600 smaller islands. New Zealand is situated some 2,000 kilometres east of Australia.
History Phase 1 Small description: New Zealand was one of the last major landmasses settled by humans. It was discovered and settled by Polynesians, who developed a distinct Māori culture. The most current reliable evidence strongly indicates that initial settlement of New Zealand occurred 1280 – 1320 CE.
History Phase 2 Small description: The first Europeans known to have reached New Zealand were Dutch explorer Abel Tasman and his crew. Europeans did not revisit New Zealand until 1769 when British explorer James Cook mapped almost the entire coastline. Numerous European and North American ships followed for trade. Between 1801 and 1840, numerous Maori inhabitants were killed during inter-tribal wars thus causing a decline in population.
History Phase 3 Small description: European settlement increased through the early decades of the 19th century. With signing of the Treaty of Waitangi in 1840 between Maori chiefs and the British, the latter established New Zealand as a colony under Queen Victoria. Discrepancies in the treaty led to disagreements and armed conflicts.
History Phase 4 Small description: At first New Zealand was administered from Australia as part of the colony of New South Wales until New Zealand became a British colony in its own right in 1841. Some 400,000 settlers came from Britain, of whom 300,000 stayed permanently.
Government: The New Zealand Parliament holds legislative power and consists of the Queen and the House of Representatives. The House of Representatives is democratically elected and a government is formed from the party or coalition with the majority of seats.
Geography: New Zealand is located in the Southern Hemisphere and is made up of two main islands and many smaller islands. New Zealand is long and narrow with a maximum width of 400 kilometres with about 15,000 km of coastline.
Small description 1: As part of the resurgence of Māori culture, the traditional crafts of carving and weaving are now more widely practised and Māori artists are increasing in number and influence. During the 1960s and 1970s many artists combined traditional Māori and Western techniques, creating unique art forms.
Small description 2: Most of the major sports played in New Zealand have British origins - Cricket, Rugby, etc. Rugby is considered the national sport. The national Rugby team, 'All Blacks' are the most successful in the history of international Rugby and the team performs a haka, a traditional Māori challenge, before international matches. New Zealand also has a strong mountaineering tradition, as seen in the success of notable New Zealander Sir Edmund Hillary, the first to climb Mount Everest.
Small description 3: The country's diverse scenery and compact size, plus government incentives, have encouraged the shooting of big-budget film productions in New Zealand, including Avatar, The Lord of the Rings, The Hobbit, The Chronicles of Narnia, King Kong and The Last Samurai.
Religion 2 Name: Do not identify with a religion

Short summary description of the place: Pakistan, officially the Islamic Republic of Pakistan, is a country in South Asia. It is the world’s sixth-most populous country with a population exceeding 212,742,631 people.
History Phase 1 Small description: Some of the earliest ancient human civilisations in South Asia originated from areas in present-day Pakistan. The Indus region, was the site of several successive ancient cultures including the Neolithic Mehrgarh and the Bronze Age Indus Valley Civilisation at Harappa and Mohenjo-Daro.
History Phase 2 Small description: The Vedic period was characterised by an Indo-Aryan culture; during this period the Vedas, the oldest scriptures associated with Hinduism, were composed, and this culture later became well established in the region. Successive ancient empires and kingdoms ruled the region, including the Mauryan empire.
History Phase 3 Small description: Successive ancient empires and kingdoms ruled the region, including the Mauryan empire. The Indo-Greek Kingdom founded by Demetrius of Bactria included Gandhara and Punjab, prospering the Greco-Buddhist culture in the region. Taxila, one of the earliest universities and centres of higher education in the world, which was established during this period.
History Phase 4 Small description: The Mughals introduced Persian literature and high culture, establishing the roots of Indo-Persian culture in the region. In the early 16th century, the region remained under the Mughal Empire ruled by Muslim emperors. By the early 18th century, increasing European influence contributed to the slow disintegration of the Mughal Empire.
Government: Pakistan is an Islamic Republic and has a multi-party parliamentary system. Members of the National Assembly are elected by the citizens. The Prime Minister is the leader of the majority rule party or a coalition in the National Assembly.
Geography: Pakistan is divided into three major geographic areas: the northern highlands, the Indus River plain, and the Balochistan Plateau.
Small description 1: Pakistan has literature in Urdu, Sindhi, Punjabi, Pashto, Baluchi, Persian, English, and many other languages. Before the 19th century, Pakistani literature consisted mainly of lyric and religious poetry, and mystical and folkloric works. During the colonial period, native literary figures were influenced by western literary realism and took up increasingly varied topics and narrative forms. Well-known figures in contemporary Pakistani Urdu literature include Josh Malihabadi, Faiz Ahmed Faiz, and Saadat Hasan Manto.
Small description 2: Four periods are recognised in Pakistani architecture: pre-Islamic, Islamic, colonial, and post-colonial. Lahore, as the occasional residence of Mughal rulers, contains many important buildings from the era. Several examples of architectural influenced by British design can be found in Lahore, Peshawar, and Karachi.
Small description 3: Music of Pakistan includes diverse music from various parts of South Asia as well as Central Asian, Middle Eastern, and modern-day Western popular music.
Small description 4: Cricket is the most popular sport in Pakistan, while field hockey, polo, and squash are also popular. Traditional sports like kabaddi and other well-known games are also played.

Short summary description of the place: Delhi, officially the National Capital Territory of Delhi (NCT), is a city and a union territory of India containing New Delhi, the capital of India.
History Phase 1 Small description: There is evidence of continuous inhabitation in Delhi since at least the 6th century BCE. The earliest architectural relics date back to the Maurya period. Remains of eight major cities have been discovered in Delhi.
History Phase 2 Small description: Foundation of the Delhi Sultanate was laid. Delhi was a major centre of Sufism during this period.
History Phase 3 Small description: Babur invaded India and founded the Mughal Empire that ruled from Delhi and Agra.
History Phase 4 Small description: During the sepoy mutiny of 1857, Delhi fell to the forces of East India Company after a fight known as the Siege of Delhi. The city came under the direct control of the British Government in 1858.
Government: Delhi is a Union Territory within India, with its own legislative assembly, high court and an executive council of ministers headed by a Chief Minister.
Geography: Delhi is situated in the northern part of India, on the banks of the River Yamuna.
Small description 1: The Archaeological Survey of India recognises 1,200 heritage buildings and 175 monuments as national heritage sites in Delhi.
Small description 2: Delhi's lengthy history as a capital city has seen the food habits of its residents be influenced by many groups that occupied the city over the centuries.
Small description 3: The New Delhi World Book Fair, held biennially at the Pragati Maidan, is the second-largest exhibition of books in the world.
Small description 4: Three World Heritage Sites—the Red Fort, Qutub Minar and Humayun's Tomb—are located in Delhi.

Short summary description of the place: Bangalore, officially known as Bengaluru, is the capital of the Indian state of Karnataka. It has a population of over ten million, making it a megacity and the third-most populous city and fifth-most populous urban agglomeration in India.
Other names: Bengaluru, Silicon Valley of India, Garden City
History Phase 1 Small description: A discovery of Stone Age artefacts during the 2001 census of India at Jalahalli, Sidhapura and Jadigenahalli, all of which are located on Bangalore's outskirts today, suggest probable human settlement around 4,000 BCE.
History Phase 2 Small description: Modern Bangalore was begun in 1537 by a vassal of the Vijayanagara Empire, Kempe Gowda I, who built a mud-brick fort for the people at the site that would become the central part of modern Bangalore.
History Phase 3 Small description: Bangalore essentially became a twin city, with the "pētē", whose residents were predominantly Kannadigas and the cantonment created by the British.
History Phase 4 Small description: Bangalore played an important role during the Indian independence movement. Mahatma Gandhi visited the city in 1927 and 1934 and addressed public meetings here.
Government: The Bruhat Bengaluru Mahanagara Palike (BBMP, Greater Bangalore Municipal Corporation) is in charge of the civic administration of the city.
Geography: The topology of Bangalore is generally flat, though the western parts of the city are hilly. The highest point is Vidyaranyapura Doddabettahalli, which is 962 metres (3,156 feet) and is situated to the north-west of the city.
Small description 1: Bangalore is known as the "Garden City of India" because of its greenery, broad streets and the presence of many public parks.
Small description 2: Kannada literature appears to have flourished in Bangalore even before Kempe Gowda laid the foundations of the city.
Small description 3: A theatre art of coastal Karnataka is often played in town hall.
Small description 4: Bangalore Karaga is one of the most important and oldest festivals of Bangalore dedicated to the Hindu Goddess Draupadi
Demographics - Languages: According to census 2011, Kannada  46%, Tamil  13.99%, Telugu 13.89%, Urdu  12%, Hindi 5.4%, Malayalam  2.8%, Marathi 1.8%

Short summary description of the place: Mumbai, also known as Bombay, the official name until 1995, is the capital city of the Indian state of Maharashtra. As of 2011 it is the most populous city in India.
Other names: Bombay, City of Seven Islands, City of Dreams, Gateway to India, Hollywood of India
History Phase 1 Small description: Mumbai is built on what was once an archipelago of seven islands: Isle of Bombay, Parel, Mazagaon, Mahim, Colaba, Worli, and Old Woman's Island (also known as Little Colaba). It is not exactly known when these islands were first inhabited.
History Phase 2 Small description: The Portuguese were actively involved in the foundation and growth of their Roman Catholic religious orders in Bombay. They called the islands by various names, which finally took the written form Bombaim.
History Phase 3 Small description: The English were in constant struggle with the Portuguese vying for  Bombay, as they recognised its strategic natural harbour and its natural isolation from land-attacks. By the middle of the 17th century the growing power of the Dutch Empire forced the English to acquire a station in western India.
History Phase 4 Small description: After India's independence in 1947, the territory of the Bombay Presidency retained by India was restructured into Bombay State.
Government: It is administered by the Municipal Corporation of Greater Mumbai (MCGM) (sometimes referred to as the Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation), formerly known as the Bombay Municipal Corporation (BMC). The MCGM is in charge of the civic and infrastructure needs of the metropolis. The Mayor is chosen through indirect election by the councillors from among themselves for a term of two and half years.
Geography: Mumbai lies at the mouth of the Ulhas River on the western coast of India, in the coastal region known as the Konkan. It sits on Salsette Island (Sashti Island), which it partially shares with the Thane district. Mumbai is bounded by the Arabian Sea to the west. Many parts of the city lie just above sea level.
Small description 1: Asiatic Society of Bombay is one of the oldest public libraries in the city.
Small description 2: Beaches are a popular tourist attraction in Mumbai.
Small description 3: One of the oldest cricket stadiums in India.
Small description 4: Mumbai is the birthplace of Indian cinema
Demographics - Languages: Mumbai has a large polyglot population like any other metropolitan city of India. Sixteen major languages of India are also spoken in Mumbai, with the most common being Marathi and its dialect East Indian, Hindi, Gujarati and English

Short summary description of the place: Australia, officially the Commonwealth of Australia, is a sovereign country comprising the mainland of the Australian continent, the island of Tasmania and numerous smaller islands.
History Phase 1 Small description: Human habitation of the Australian continent is estimated to have begun around 65,000 to 70,000 years ago with the migration of people by land bridges and short sea-crossings from what is now Southeast Asia.
History Phase 2 Small description: The first recorded European sighting of the Australian mainland, and the first recorded European landfall on the Australian continent (in 1606), are attributed to the Dutch.
History Phase 3 Small description: A gold rush began in Australia in the early 1850s and the Eureka Rebellion against mining license fees in 1854 was an early expression of civil disobedience.
History Phase 4 Small description: On 1 January 1901, federation of the colonies was achieved after a decade of planning, consultation and voting. This established the Commonwealth of Australia as a dominion of the British Empire.
Government: Australia is a federal parliamentary constitutional monarchy. Elizabeth II reigns as Queen of Australia. Since she resides in the United Kingdom, she is represented in Australia by the governor-general at the federal level and by the governors at the state level, who by convention act on the advice of her ministers.
Geography: Surrounded by the Indian and Pacific oceans, Australia is the world's smallest continent and sixth largest country by total area. Owing to its size and isolation, it is often called the "island continent", and is sometimes considered the world's largest island.
Small description 1: The Royal Exhibition Building in Melbourne was the first building in Australia to be listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 2004.
Small description 2: Vegemite, pavlova, lamingtons and meat pies are regarded as iconic Australian foods.
Small description 3: The Melbourne Cricket Ground is strongly associated with the history and development of cricket and Australian rules football, Australia's two most popular spectator sports.
Small description 4: Seven Little Australians by Ethel Turner is the first and only book by an Australian author to have been continuously in print for 100 years.
Demographics - Languages: Although Australia has no official language, English has always been entrenched as the de facto national language. Australian English differs slightly from other varieties of English in grammar and spelling

Short summary description of the place: Chennai is the capital of the Indian state of Tamil Nadu. Located on the Coromandel Coast off the Bay of Bengal, it is the biggest cultural, economic and educational centre of south India.
History Phase 1 Small description: Stone age implements have been found near Pallavaram in Chennai. According to the Archaeological Survey of India, Pallavaram was a megalithic cultural establishment, and pre-historic communities resided in the settlement.
History Phase 2 Small description: From the 1st–12th century the region of present Tamil Nadu and parts of South India was ruled by the Cholas
History Phase 3 Small description: The Portuguese first arrived in 1522 and built a port called São Tomé after the Christian apostle, St. Thomas, who is believed to have preached in the area between 52 and 70 CE. In 1612, the Dutch established themselves near Pulicat, north of Chennai.
History Phase 4 Small description: By the 18th century, the British had conquered most of the region around Tamil Nadu and the northern modern–day states of Andhra Pradesh and Karnataka, establishing the Madras Presidency with Madras as the capital. Gradually, the city grew into a major naval base and became the central administrative centre for the British in South India.
Geography: Chennai is located on the south–eastern coast of India in the north–eastern part of Tamil Nadu on a flat coastal plain known as the Eastern Coastal Plains.
Small description 1: Chennai is home to many museums, galleries, and other institutions, many of which are free of admission charges and are major tourist attractions as well as playing a research role.
Small description 2: An arts festival called the Chennai Sangamam, which showcases not only various art of Tamil Nadu, but also from the neighbouring states, like kalari (from Kerala), which is a major attraction, is held in January every year.

Short summary description of the place: Kolkata is the capital of the Indian state of West Bengal. The city is widely regarded as the "cultural capital" of India, and is also nicknamed the "City of Joy".
History Phase 1 Small description: The discovery and archaeological study of Chandraketugarh, 35 kilometres (22 mi) north of Kolkata, provide evidence that the region in which the city stands has been inhabited for over two millennia.
History Phase 2 Small description: Kolkata's recorded history began in 1690 with the arrival of the English East India Company, which was consolidating its trade business in Bengal. The area occupied by the present-day city encompassed three villages: Kalikata, Gobindapur, and Sutanuti.
History Phase 3 Small description: In 1712, the British completed the construction of Fort William, located on the east bank of the Hooghly River to protect their trading factory. In 1793, ruling power of the Nawabs were abolished and East India company took complete control of the city and the province.
History Phase 4 Small description: By the 1850s, Calcutta had two areas: White Town, which was primarily British and centred on Chowringhee and Dalhousie Square; and Black Town, mainly Indian and centred on North Calcutta. The city underwent rapid industrial growth starting in the early 1850s, especially in the textile and jute industries; this encouraged British companies to massively invest in infrastructure projects, which included telegraph connections and Howrah railway station.
Geography: Spread roughly north–south along the east bank of the Hooghly River, Kolkata sits within the lower Ganges Delta of eastern India approximately 75 km (47 mi) west of the international border with Bangladesh.
Small description 1: Kolkata has been called the "City of Furious, Creative Energy" as well as the "cultural [or literary] capital of India".
Small description 2: Kolkata has many buildings adorned with Indo-Islamic and Indo-Saracenic architectural motifs. Several well-maintained major buildings from the colonial period have been declared "heritage structures".
Small description 3: Kolkata is the home of the Bengali cinema industry, dubbed "Tollywood" for Tollygunj, where most of the state's film studios are located.
Small description 4: Though Bengali women traditionally wear the sari, the shalwar kameez and Western attire is gaining acceptance among younger women. Western-style dress has greater acceptance among men, although the traditional dhoti and kurta are seen during festivals.

Short summary description of the place: Hyderabad is the capital of the Indian state of Telangana and de jure capital of Andhra Pradesh
History Phase 1 Small description: Archaeologists excavating near the city have unearthed Iron Age sites that may date from 500 BCE.
History Phase 2 Small description: Until 1874 there were no modern industries in Hyderabad. With the introduction of railways in the 1880s, four factories were built to the south and east of Hussain Sagar Lake,[27] and during the early 20th century, Hyderabad was transformed into a modern city.
History Phase 3 Small description: The Constitution of India, which became effective on 26 January 1950, made Hyderabad State one of the part B states of India, with Hyderabad city continuing to be the capital.
History Phase 4 Small description: On 1 November 1956 the states of India were reorganised by language. Hyderabad state was split into three parts, which were merged with neighbouring states to form the modern states of Maharashtra, Karnataka and Andhra Pradesh.
Geography: Situated in the southern part of Telangana in southeastern India, Hyderabad is 1,566 kilometres south of Delhi, 699 kilometres southeast of Mumbai, and 570 kilometres north of Bangalore by road.
Small description 1: Organisations engaged in the advancement of literature include the Sahitya Akademi, the Urdu Academy, the Telugu Academy, the National Council for Promotion of Urdu Language, the Comparative Literature Association of India, and the Andhra Saraswata Parishad.
Small description 2: The state government organises the Golconda Music and Dance Festival, the Taramati Music Festival and the Premavathi Dance Festival to further encourage the development of music.
Small description 3: The region is well known for its Golconda and Hyderabad painting styles which are branches of Deccani painting.
Small description 4: Hyderabadi cuisine comprises a broad repertoire of rice, wheat and meat dishes and the skilled use of various spices.

Short summary description of the place: Mohali is a city in the Mohali district in Punjab, India. It is located close to Chandigarh.
History Phase 1 Small description: The area was also known to be a part of the Indus Valley Civilisation
History Phase 2 Small description: The village of Mohali was a part of the Sikh Empire. A battle took place here between the British and Sikh soldiers.
History Phase 3 Small description: The area around Mohali Village was developed as an industrial estate close to Chandigarh. In 1975 the foundation of Mohali township was laid.
Small description 1: Mohali has 8 multipurpose sports complexes and an international cricket stadium.
Small description 2: Gurudwara Amb Sahib is a historical shrine situated in Mohali that commemorates the visit of 7th Guru of Sikhs, Guru Har Rai.

Short summary description of the place: Ranchi is the capital of the Indian state of Jharkhand.
History Phase 1 Small description: Magadha Empire exercised indirect control over the territory that is in modern day Ranchi
History Phase 2 Small description: During the expansion of the Mughal Empire, the sovereign status of the local kingdoms was affected but they continued to rule the region
History Phase 3 Small description: After Battle of Buxar in 1764, Nagvanshi kings of this region became vassals of the East India Company
History Phase 4 Small description: During the period of the British Raj, the region witnessed a number of uprisings and revolts. Birsa Munda played a prominent role.
Small description 1: Ranchi is centre for numerous sports activities, including cricket, hockey, and football. The National Games were held here in 2011.
Small description 2: Cricketer Mahendra Singh Dhoni is from Ranchi
Demographics - Languages: Hindi,  Nagpuri, Mundari, Khortha and Kurmali

Short summary description of the place: Chandigarh is a city and a union territory in India that serves as the capital of the two neighbouring states of Punjab and Haryana.
History Phase 1 Small description: The Chandigarh region is assumed to have been inhabited during the period of the Indus Valley Civilisation.
History Phase 2 Small description: After the partition of India, Lahore the earlier capital of the state of Punjab became a part of Pakistan. Chandigarh was created in 1960 to serve as the capital of Punjab and the new state of Haryana, which was created in 1966.
History Phase 3 Small description: Chandigarh was developed as a planned city with modern architecture, green spaces, neighbourhoods, and traffic segregation.
Small description 1: The master plan of the city was prepared by Swiss-French architect Le Corbusier who also designed several iconic buildings and monuments in the city.
Small description 2: Among the many festivals celebrated in Chandigarh, the Rose Festival in Zakir Hussain Rose Garden in February every year, shows thousands of subspecies of roses.

Short summary description of the place: Jaipur is the capital and the largest city of the Indian state of Rajasthan. As of 2011, the city had a population of 3.1 million, making it the tenth most populous city in the country.
History Phase 1 Small description: The city of Jaipur was founded in 1727 by Jai Singh II, the Raja of Amer who ruled from 1699 to 1743.
History Phase 2 Small description: The construction of the city began in 1726 and took four years to complete the major roads, offices, and palaces. The city was divided into nine blocks, two of which contained the state buildings and palaces, with the remaining seven allotted to the public. Huge ramparts were built, pierced by seven fortified gates.
History Phase 3 Small description: In the 19th century, the city grew rapidly and by 1900 it had a population of 160,000.
Geography: Jaipur has a hot semi-arid climate. It receives over 63 cm of rainfall annually. Most rains occur in the monsoon months between June and September.
Small description 1: Jawahar Kala Kendra (JKK) is a multi arts centre located in Jaipur in India. It was built by Rajasthan government with the purpose of preserving Rajasthani arts and crafts.
Small description 2: The Jaipur Gharana of Kathak is known for its rapid intricate dance forms, vivacious body movements and subtle Abhinaya.
Small description 3: Typical dishes include Dal Baati Churma, an Indian dish comprising dal (lentils) and baati (hard wheat rolls).
Small description 4: There are statues depicting Rajasthani culture around the city.
Demographics - Languages: The official language of Jaipur is Hindi and the additional official language is English. The main language of the city is Rajasthani. Marwari, Hindi and English are also spoken in the city.
